00034 // finds integer (32bit) elements in a set (n elements) and returns indices - only one (the first) match
00035 // is reported per element
00036 // a vector "matches" of length n_elements has to be provided
00037 void pmatchi(long* elements, long* n_elements, long* set, long* n_set, long* matches);
00038 
00039 // finds character elements in a set (n elements) and returns indices - only one (the first) match
00040 // is reported per element
00041 // a vector "matches" of length n_elements has to be provided
00042 void pmatchc(char** elements, long* n_elements, char** set, long* n_set, long* matches);
00043 
00044 // finds a character element in a set and returns boolean match vector
00045 // a vector "matches" of length n_set has to be provided
00046 void matchc(char* element, char** set, long* n_set, bool* matches);
00047 
00048 // finds a integer element in a set and returns boolean match vector
00049 // a vector "matches" of length n_set has to be provided
00050 void matchi(long* element, long* set, long* n_set, bool* matches);

00053 // interpolation on a table: code (w/ adapted indices) from Numerical Recipes, 2rd ed., chapter 3.1
00054 // added wrapping function interp which allows to chose degree of interpolation polynomial
00055 // (1 = linear, 2 = quadratic, etc.)
00056 void locate(float* xx, long* n, float* x, long* j);
00057 void polint(float* xa, float* ya, long* n, float* x, float *y, float *dy);

00070 /*      From Numerical Recipes in C, 2nd ed., 1992:
00071         Using Ridders' method, return the root of a function func known to lie between x1 and x2.
00072         The root, returned as zriddr, will be refined to an approximate accuracy xacc.
00073  */
00074 float zriddr(float (*func)(float,void*), void * params, float x1, float x2, float xacc);
